title: Aulne, Kansas
text:
Aulne is an <a href="Unincorporated%20area">unincorporated community</a> in <a href="Marion%20County%2C%20Kansas">Marion County, Kansas</a>, United States. The Aulne name was suggested by officials of the railroad when it was built through Aulne during the 19th century. It is located southwest of <a href="Marion%2C%20Kansas">Marion</a> at the intersection of Pawnee Road and 140th Street next to the <a href="Union%20Pacific%20Railroad">Union Pacific Railroad</a>.
History.
Early history.
For many millennia, the <a href="Great%20Plains">Great Plains</a> of North America was inhabited by <a href="nomadic">nomadic</a> <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native Americans</a>. From the 16th century to 18th century, the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20France">Kingdom of France</a> claimed ownership of large parts of North America. In 1762, after the <a href="French%20and%20Indian%20War">French and Indian War</a>, France secretly ceded <a href="New%20France">New France</a> to <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, per the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Fontainebleau%20%281762%29">Treaty of Fontainebleau</a>.
19th century.
In 1802, Spain returned most of the land to France. In 1803, most of the land for <a href="History%20of%20Kansas">modern day Kansas</a> was acquired by the United States from France as part of the 828,000 square mile <a href="Louisiana%20Purchase">Louisiana Purchase</a> for 2.83 <a href="Penny%20%28United%20States%20coin%29">cents</a> per <a href="acre">acre</a>.
In 1854, the <a href="Kansas%20Territory">Kansas Territory</a> was organized, then in 1861 <a href="Kansas">Kansas</a> became the 34th <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a>. In 1855, <a href="Marion%20County%2C%20Kansas">Marion County</a> was established within the <a href="Kansas%20Territory">Kansas Territory</a>, which included the land for modern day Aulne.
In 1872, a railroad contractor, named Col. W. Sherburn, decided the location would be good location for a town and named it after himself, Sherburn, but it was too early and never used.
In 1887, the <a href="Chicago%2C%20Kansas%20and%20Nebraska%20Railway">Chicago, Kansas and Nebraska Railway</a> built a branch line north–south from <a href="Herington%2C%20Kansas">Herington</a> through Aulne to <a href="Caldwell%2C%20Kansas">Caldwell</a>. It foreclosed in 1891 and was taken over by <a href="Chicago%2C%20Rock%20Island%20and%20Pacific%20Railway">Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway</a>, which shut down in 1980, and reorganized as <a href="Oklahoma%2C%20Kansas%20and%20Texas%20Railroad">Oklahoma, Kansas and Texas Railroad</a> which merged in 1988 with <a href="Missouri%20Pacific%20Railroad">Missouri Pacific Railroad</a>, and finally merged in 1997 with <a href="Union%20Pacific%20Railroad">Union Pacific Railroad</a>. Most locals still refer to this railroad as the "Rock Island".
A post office existed in Aulne from August 19, 1887, to February 28, 1954.
20th century.
Aulne was one of the finalist communities considered for <a href="Tabor%20College%20%28Kansas%29">Tabor College</a> before it was established in <a href="Hillsboro%2C%20Kansas">Hillsboro</a> in 1908.
During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, the local telephone company decreed that "No German could be spoken over the telephones", because of 
<a href="anti-German%20sentiment">anti-German sentiment</a> towards German-Americans.
Geography.
Aulne is located roughly halfway between <a href="Marion%2C%20Kansas">Marion</a> and <a href="Peabody%2C%20Kansas">Peabody</a> next to the <a href="Union%20Pacific%20Railroad">Union Pacific Railroad</a>.
Education.
The community is served by <a href="Marion%E2%80%93Florence%20USD%20408">Marion–Florence USD 408</a> public school district. All students attend schools in <a href="Marion%2C%20Kansas">Marion</a>. The high school is a member of T.E.E.N., a shared video teaching network between five area high schools.
Infrastructure.
Transportation.
<a href="U.S.%20Route%2056%20%28Kansas%29">U.S. Route 56</a> is to the north, <a href="U.S.%20Route%2050%20%28Kansas%29">U.S. Route 50</a> is to the south, and <a href="U.S.%20Route%2077%20%28Kansas%29">U.S. Route 77</a> is east of the community. The Oklahoma Kansas Texas (OKT) line of the <a href="Union%20Pacific%20Railroad">Union Pacific Railroad</a> runs through the community, but it no longer has a side-spur at Aulne.
